logEntry: Added the wreck of the Martha (known as the Grass Wreck) to the site. We are increasing the area which our site covers down beyond Stonehaven. While strictly outside of our traditional area of operations
column3: there are some interesting wrecks with great stories south of Aberdeen and we think they would benefit from thorough identification and documentation on our site."

logEntry: We visited a very promising mark today.  We really thought, finally, this would be the wreck of the SS Malmland.  Unfortunately, it turned out to be a pile of massive boulders lying on the seabed.  We have named it Rachael's Reef" in honour of Rachael who had her first dive with us today."

We visited the wreck previously identified as the Bel Lily for the first time in 26 years. We found a steam trawler, upright and largely intact. A maker's plate identified her as Hall Russell-built in Aberdeen. Based on the dive video, her layout and damage suggest she is almost certainly the Strathclunie, which sank in a collision in January 1928. All crew members were rescued.

In 2012, we found and dived what we believed were the remains of three distinct wrecks spread out over 100m running due north/south. Having reviewed the footage taken on that dive, we have now identified that she is in fact a single, but badly damaged wreck. Given the extent of the damage and the wreck's proximity to the minefield laid by UC 49, we believe she is the Bel Lily. The wreck we had identified in 1999 as the Bel Lily
column3: further to the north east has been set to 'Unknown' until we get a chance to revisit and identify her."

logEntry: More desktop digging. The wreck which we had previously identified as the steam dredger Subworker is actually the dredger TIC No. 8. A review of the positional information plus the distinctive stanchions seen during the dive give us a certain identification. She was lost on her maiden voyage to Newcastle with all 5 crew while under tow in 1911. See the new page here"
More research of WW2 U-boat logs has finally given us a name for the Knock Wreck just off Fraserburgh. She is the Swedish vessel Svarton sunk by the U-58 in January 1940."

After more research we now believe the wreck which we had identified as the Ethel Gwendoline is in fact the Parkhill. It is likely that the Ethel Gwendoline is in deep water about 6 miles east of Rattray Head. We have added the Parkhill to the website."
Added the unknown trawler, which we discovered in 2023, to the website. We will need more work to confirm its identity but we believe she is the Caersin."

After an almost two year break, we returned to exploration this year and visited a new mark just off Aberdeen near to the two HM Trawlers found in 2023. We believe this wreck to be the steam trawler Virgilia."

Visited the wreck which we sounded in April 2021. The divers were from a Plymouth based group - Gasperadoes - who are experienced in diving to over 100m. Pictures and video from the dive allow us to positively confirmed her to be the wreck of the U 77."
Jim was lucky enough to be involved with the group who have found and dived the battlecruiser HMS Hawke, 85 miles east of Fraserburgh.

Returned to the SS Bretagne again today, armed with a list of activities to determine if she is, in fact, the SS Malmland. It seems though, our original identification is correct! She is the Bretagne. The hunt for the Malmland continues.

Dived a new mark today, off the mouth of the Ythan. Only in 40m, and very silty. We had believed this to be a WWI loss, an admiralty water tanker, but it turned out to be a reasonably well preserved steam trawler. We have work to do to identify it. A lovely dive though.
Dived the wreck of the SS Bretagne today to attempt further identification. One huge boiler seen
column3: but close to the bow and next to a massive boiler cradle
column4: perhaps for another boiler - which would put our original identification into question. We will revisit for more investigation tomorrow."

logEntry: We couldn't dive our intended target today so selected to return to HMT Ormonde to try to get a more positive ID. The webpage will be updated with new photographs and dive information."

We visited the site of the Ethel Gwendoline today. A more detailed sonar survey of the wreck had indicated a 2nd hull beside the first one. We were unable to find any trace of a 2nd hull, but we found information which means we need to go back to the drawing board on the identification of the wreck. She can't be the Ethel Gwendoline.
A further work-up day, we visited the St Magnus. In lovely vis
column3: we were able to get a good look at her and discovered a possible further clue to her demise. Look out for updates to her website entry."

logEntry: Our season started yesterday with a work up dive on the SS Wrangler to get back in practice. All went well and we spotted a very interesting mark
column3: looking like a small puffer or steam fishing vessel which we returned to explore today. It turned out to be a perfectly shaped granite reef!"

logEntry: Another super dive today in great conditions. We set out to dive the southerly mark of the New Triangle" wrecks and found the HMT Robert Bowen
column3: lost 9/2/1940 with all hands during the action which sank the HMT Fort Royal"

logEntry: After a few days off due to boat problems we hit the seas again in perfect conditions. We dived the wreck known as the 33-Fathom to do more work to identify her. It is pretty certain from her cargo, size, general arrangement and cylinder diameters that she is the SS Dungonnell lost without trace on a voyage from Shields to Belfast in 1903.
Updated the website with reports on the two new wrecks discovered this month. The SS Kathleen and the WW2 armed trawler

We dived the westerly mark of a group of three wrecks 8 miles off Balmedie. A great dive in super visibility. We found the remains of an armed trawler and are working on her identification. More soon.

We returned to the unknown wreck referred to as the 33 Fathom to make a further attempt at identification. We did not find anything definitive on our dive but have a much more detailed understanding of her structure and cargo now, which will help another attempt to identify her.

We have positively identified the wreck first dived on 14 July as the Crisabelle Stephen and have added this to the website. We also returned to the Hydrographic Office mark dived on 15th July and retrieved the ship's bell which identified her as the SS Kathleen
column3: lost at sea with all crew in January 1914"

logEntry: It's been an excruciatingly slow start to the season! A combination of boat problems, poor weather and other holidays meant that we started late. However, in the last couple of days we have dived two new marks off of the river Ythan, the 24 Fathom mark and a Hydrographic Office mark in 74m. Lovely wrecks, we are in the process of assessing all the information we collected on the dive in an attempt to name them. More soon.
We have a confirmed find of the U 77. Very exciting! After weeks lost to diving through poor weather and now boat problems
column3: we managed to get out on a mark and took video footage from the surface. This footage confirms the wreck of a submarine lying 100m below us. From research conducted by Kevin Heath and Michael Lowrey
column4: this can only be the U 77 lost in 1916."

logEntry: The weather has not been kind to us in the last week. Great sea conditions, but fog and mist every day has made diving impossible. On the only diveable day, we attempted to dive the Knock Wreck" to try to find more clues to her identity but strong spring tides made that impossible. However
column4: glassy seas and sun! We dived the Taylor. A lovely small
column5: but very intact steamer. We have new photos on the wreck page."

logEntry: Perfect conditions for the long trip south to dive Hunks Big Wreck" which we have long suspected to be the Trevorian. A lovely dive
column3: no absolute positive ID but number and design of boilers
column4: plus size of wreck makes it highly likely that she is the Trevorian."

logEntry: An exciting trip to a new mark from the hydrographic survey. A steamship" in 70m
column4: 60m long. Very excited to see what it was. We arrived in perfect glassy seas to have a wonderful dive on a rock reef! Not another wreck to add to our list."

logEntry: A long trip south to dive the unidentified 33-Fathom" for further exploration. Unfortunately our shot was off the wreck and we were unable to find it in the poor visibility in this area."
A lovely dive on the Windward Ho I had forgotten just how intact she is. Her bows are intact and her hull has a good 3-4m height here."
Dived the Sofie Bakke for the first time in many years. A grand old lady who hasn't changed much in the interval. We mainly dived around her massive diesel engines. Some new photos on the page."
We returned to the St Fergus for further exploration. She is not broken in two as previously thought
column3: however significant damage to bow area. Updates on the page."

logEntry: Bad weather and equipment failures over last couple of weeks kept us from visiting the St Fergus again
column3: however we managed to get in on the SS Simonburn and the lovely SS Muriel. Super dives
column4: but the season has had a typically weather interrupted start!"

logEntry: Dived SS Cairnmona and HMS Flotta in fantastic visibility. Pages have been updated with new pictures by Naomi Watson."
Diving has restarted for this year with a work-up dive on the SS Cairnmona. We dived in the area of the bridge and found a lovely telegraph
column3: the helm and lots of port-holes."

logEntry: Sounded a new mark in 103m north of Fraserburgh. We think this will be a very special wreck and are working up to dive it and confirm its identity later in the season.
We explored a new wreck in 75m, 5 miles east of Rattray Head, we believe her to be the St Fergus but we will need to revisit her for further confirmation."
